reviewText:
This one of the best first person shooter games I've ever played, plain and simple.

Half Life 2 begins 20 years after the original Half Life. As Gordon Freeman awakens from stasis he finds himself on a train heading to City 17 which is overrun by the combine. You find yourself as the leader of the resistance and you must take down the Combine.

Half Life 2 is at this point one of the best received games and I'm sure pretty much everyone has played it. If not well what the hell are you doing reading this review ? You need to go buy this game straight away and play it right now.

The game is a simple first person shooter, but it does plenty things different than the regular first person shooters. You have a health bar and you have to do platforming to solve some of the puzzles.  Not to mention the source engine physics are absolutely insane.

For a game that came out back in 2004 it still looks amazing. Now while it does have so low res textures it's still looks breath taking, like in the final chapters.

The game for the most part is pretty easy. I played through the game without a problem, even though some segments were tough due to the fast movement you have to pull off to avoid gunfire. Not to mention the Strider battles are incredibly intense and quite difficult.

The game took me 10 hours to finish. I felt this was the perfect amount of time for the price I paid for it and this was worth every single penny.

Apart from the single playthrough there's not much replay value. The only reason to replay it twice is to look for the G-Man Easter eggs.

In the end Half Life 2 is a fantastic game. It's a must own for everyone who is a gamer. This game is a piece of history and without a doubt one of the best games I have ever played in my entire life.

I experienced zero problems while playing the game. I ran the game on ultra settings 60 FPS the entire time of playing. This game runs really well and should run on pretty much all systems.

Final Rating:
9.5/10 -  A Must own and must play

reviewText:
NOTE: Related ContentAlso see my:
Half-Life (1) Review
Half-Life: Opposing Force Review
Half-Life: Blue Shift Review
Black Mesa Review

TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Half-Life 2 is a first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve Software (Corporation) and is a sequel to the extremely popular and revolutionary 1998 game Half-Life. Half-Life 2 was originally released back in 2004 and was then boasting the newly developed, highly flexible and powerful Source Engine, it then became an instant classic by making good use of new technology, excellent storytelling, gameplay mechanics and an unrivaled online experience. Alongside its predecessor, both games left a lasting impression, particularly on the FPS genre, as an industry standard for future FPS games to come.

PLOT (No Spoilers):Half-Life 2 puts the player once more behind the thick-framed bulletproof glasses of Gordon Freeman, an MIT Graduate of Theoretical Physics with an uncanny ability to wield military hardware and the person indirectly responsible for opening a portal to an alien world and exposing Earth to an invasion that is to be known as the 'Black Mesa Incident'. Half-Life 2 is set 20 years after the events of Half-Life 1 and the world is now under the full control of the 'Combine', an interdimensional empire that is currently harvesting the natural resources of Earth including the human race which is now close to extinction.

PROS:+ Graphics and artstyle that looks just as good as it is now (2015), as it was eleven years ago (2004).
+ Excellent sequel with an excellent story that expands the Half-Life Universe
+ Excellent memorable supporting characters such as Alyx Vance
+ Great sound quality, facial animation, and voice acting adds to the immersive experience
+ Excellent enemy AI
+ Great level and environment designs but...(see CON #1)
+ Fun gunplay and gameplay mechanics
+ Good selection of weapons and equipment with very creative special abilities (Gravity Gun)
+ Atmospheric with excellent use of lighting, sound effects and environment design
+ Challenging difficulties
+ Expanded levels that give some room for exploration, but doesn't destroy the narrative storytelling
+ Lengthy game time
+ Very affordable price (though I highly recommend the Half-Life Complete pack)
+ Multiplayer is still active as far as I can tell
+ Tons of available mods that expand player experience

CONS:- Driving section may be a little too long but it does offer a few 'stops' where the player can stretch his leg muscles and trigger finger.
- The Squad Support AI is down right suicidal with no command to tell them to stay in place for more than 15 seconds before they follow you again. (This is annoying specially if you're trying to keep them alive against particularly deadly opponents such as Striders)
- Rag-doll physics engine can be unrealistically (albeit hilariously) glitchy
- No Steam Workshop Support for the multitude of MODS that are available.

CONCLUSION:Much like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 is a MASTERPIECE of a game and is a MUST BUY and MUST OWN for any fan of the first person genre because how else can you describe a game that is almost 11 years old, yet, can still retain all the fun and excitement of a recently released title.

WORTH IT?:If you decide to purchase and try this game, I do recommend you purchase Half-Life: Complete so you may also avail of the two Episodes that was subsequently released.

FINAL NOTES:Half-Life 2's use of the amazing Source engine reflects on the fact that this game's graphics, despite showing some age, still manages not only to look good, but also to look authentic and atmospheric with its excellent use of sound and music that makes the environment feel alive. Graphics aside, the gameplay has survived for even after a decade and has still not lost its charm. The enemy AI provides an imposing challenge while gunplay and the creative weapons creates one of the most fun and immersive experience you can get on a first-person shooter. Storywise, the Half-Life universe can be considered as one of the most beautifully crafted worlds in gaming history. Half-Life 2 fully emphasizes this point with its amazing and memorable supporting characters that can establish a connection with the player on an emotional level. To recap, Half-Life 2 is the game that once again redefined how modern first-person shooters will be made in the future and remains as the benchmark for good single player FPS gaming experience.

reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is a BLAST to play. Pretty much everything in the game is interactive. You pick up paint cans with the gravity gun and when the can hits, it splatters the object with paint. It always fun to pick up a saw blade and toss it at a creature splitting it in half. If its there you can almost be assured that it can be used.

The controls in Half-Life 2 are the exact same as the original Half-Life so veterans will be able to pick up and go very easily. For newcomers to the series the controls are very easy to pick up and very practical. After playing with this control scheme you probably will set all of your FPS games to it.

I played the game in normal difficulty and it was pretty challenging, but not too hard. I found myself reloading a lot, and even after doing parts in the games over and over again I was still having fun trying to pass it, unlike some other games I have tried. Even though you may load a lot I found that ammo was hardly an issue. The supply crates are pretty much random and give you what you need the most. So if you are running low in shotgun shells, the next crate probably will contain some. This is helpful but at times I felt that I had too much ammo.

The story takes place a number of years after the Black Mesa incident. The G-man awakes you on a train and talks to you for a moment and then vanishes. You soon get off the train and arrive at a place called â€œCity 17â€, ran by a dictator figure known as Dr. Breen, your former administrator at Black Mesa. You don't really know why you are there, or how you got there and the Combine roaming around the streets don't seem too friendly. You play through the entire game through Gordon Freeman's eyes really immersing you in the game.

I was always in awe throughout the whole game. This game has the best graphics I have seen on any game. The people look life-like. They display their emotions so well that you know what they are feeling. The buildings and the atmosphere are awe-inspiring. You may never want to leave City 17 after you see its beauty. The different lighting in each area was great. You actually felt like you were progressing through the game when you start out in day time, and soon you see the sun setting and then it gets dark again.

The music in this game was awesome. You could tell when a big battle was coming because the music would start playing, and your blood would start pumping. The music made the game that much more enjoyable. I listen to the soundtrack and I can see the battles without actually playing the game. That in my opinion is what makes the battles so great.

The sound in the game was great. I loved the sound the combines made when they died. Each character had a distinct voice and had astounding voice acting. I have never been as freaked in a game when I hear a howl off in the distance and hear a rain gutter banging letting me know that a fast zombie is climbing up after me. The only reason why this score got a 9 is that there is some stuttering when the game loads or auto saves which can be very annoying.

This game took me more than 20 hours to complete after playing around in the game with the physics and such, so it wasn't that short of a game, especially for an FPS. This game is definitely replayable. After playing through the game I invited my friend over so he could play it. He found different ways to kill creatures and solve puzzles that I never thought of, so that in itself is a great reason to replay the game. Also the game on hard is much more difficult than normal giving you more challenge as you go around a second time. Why an 8 then? Well the multiplayer is non-existent as of right now so I can't see myself playing it as much as I could be.

This game is the best game this year. The graphics, physics, AI, music and sound strung around a well woven story make for a great time. You should definitely buy this game. If you computer can't handle it then its worth the price of upgrading.

reviewText:
We remember the Freeman. We are coterminous. There is no distance between us. No false veils of time or space may intervene. We see you still in Black Mesa. Clearly we see you in the Nihilanth's chamber. We bear witness to the bright eternity of the Nihilanth's demise. You leap, you fall, we see you flash between the barriers. We are there still, in observance of your final stroke. While our own lay scattered at your feet, you severed the vortal cord that bound the Nihilanth to life, and to us. That sharp spur of hope has not dulled to this day. For once the lesser master lay defeated, we knew the greater must also fall in time.

For a brief time you joined with us. You are one. Between the worlds. Communion of the Vortessence. And that other: a deeper mystery. No deeper than the void itself. We cannot forget those whose cords you cut. Forgiveness is not ours to bestow. Unity of purpose, the shattering of common shackles, a single road we tread. Your song we sing and shall sing for eternity. No matter the consequences of this struggle. You have brought us grief and jubilation beyond measure. With you beside us, a talisman of victory, the day of freedom draws nigh.

Your bright face obscures your darker mask. We call you sib, although your mind and meaning are a mystery to us. Far distant eyes look out through yours. Something secret steers us both. We shall not name it. We have endured these chafing bonds for eons, yet a single moment of further servitude seems intolerable! How often have we slipped our yoke, only to find it choking us again. Let this war end in either total victory or our extinction. No further compromise shall we allow. We take our stand beside you, here, upon this miserable rock.

The way ahead is dark for the moment. What seems to you a sacrifice is merely, to us, an oscillation. We do not fear the interval of darkness. We are a tapestry woven of Vortessence. It is the same for you if only you would see it. How many are there in you? Whose hopes and dreams do you encompass? Could you but see the eyes inside your own, the minds in your mind, you would see how much we share.

We are you, Freeman. And you are us.

reviewText:
(Re-written review)
Half-Life 2, an ageless classic of PC games, the title that put Valve on the map, the reason Steam exists today and one of the most ground-breaking titles of it's time. I'm going to say right now to those who haven't played Half-Life 2 to do so immediately, as it is an incredible game that to me has triumphed over the tests of time and remains high on the list of video games that can never be bested.
Half-Life 2 is just about perfect in every regard: from it's carefully forged story to the perfected pacing, from unforgettable characters to a steady challenge curve. The entirety of Half-Life 2 is a journey leading the player full circle in their quest to liberate humanity from their omnipresent multidimensional conquerers, the Combine.
But if the game wasn't already grand enough, Valve gives the player ultimate control over their physics engine with the highly beloved Gravity Gun (you can call it the Zero-Point Energy Manipulator, if you really want to), a weapon that has never been equaled in any game since. The Gravity Gun allows you to pick up objects from the world, like barrels, sawblades, crates and anything you can move and use them as protection against enemy fire or throw them at your foes in a satisfying method. This is even encouraged by the developers, for the level immediately after you recieve the Gravity Gun you are placed in a zombie-infested town with limited ammo and plenty of sharp, explosive or otherwise deadly-when-hurled-at-100kph objects. In other words: A playground for your new best friend.
So if you're a recent gamer looking for a timeless classic or a veteran tired of all the two-weapon inventory crap in modern games, I sincerely and whole-heartedly recommend Half-Life 2 for an experience that has never been topped.

reviewText:
So back when Valve knew how to develop video games...

In the past 5 years - that is, since I first got The Orange Box - I have started many playthroughs of Half-Life 2. And I have always given up during the first few airboat sections. I thought it was nothing more than a boring shooter and I just couldn't keep myself interested at all. But now, almost 11 years after its initial release, I suddenly decided that it's the right time to give it another chance.

And after finishing it I don't regret a single minute.

It's true, let's face it. The game only truly starts after you get away from that airboat, and then... Pure awesomeness commences. It's so fantastically designed that the gunfights never feel boring, there's one action after another, every single location is filled with its own unique atmosphere and while the story isn't the most creative or breathtaking one, the game more than makes up for it with everything else. It feels so great to play, and you have to play it yourself to really understand.

Applause to Valve and a slap in my face for not playing this masterpiece earlier. One of the best video games ever made.

reviewText: Six years is a long wait for a sequel, but it was well worth it.  In that time, Valve created their own game engine, known as Source, and with the Gravity Gun quickly became THE game to copy.  Like ClassicDOOM before it, most FPS games that came after Half-Life 2 valiantly attempted to copy the in-game physics engine that allows to to catch and repel in-game props.  Many of them succeeded, but Half-Life 2 was the first to do it, and gamers know where to give credit where credit is due.\n\nOnce again, you play as Gordon Freeman, mute savior of humankind.  Reawakened by the G-Man from the previous game some time later
date: you find that the world as you know it is no longer.  The Combine have successfully invaded and subjuated humanity, and it's only a matter of time before Man becomes just another X-stamp on the Combine's evolutionary whiteboard.  Unless you can rise up to the challenge of liberating your very species, that time will approach far quicker than you'd like.\n\nOne of the first FPS games to introduce drivable vehicles, adding the Gravity Gun is just icing on this cake (that's a metaphor, not a lie).  Chock full of references and easter-eggs, Valve should be proud that their title has continued to successfully carry the FPS banner.

reviewText:
Since this is a first person shooter, let's talk about the guns. For starters you have the basic weapons, pistols, machine guns, a shotgun, grenades, rocket launcher (RPG?) and so on. Some weapons have dual uses like the machine gun has a grenade launcher. The weapons feel very good to use. The pistol has never been so much fun to shoot wow! I'm shocked. The machine guns have real kick to them. The shotgun seems very effective. The rocket launcher is laser guided, which is fun to take down helicopters with. Launch it and guide it to the helicopter, because if you shoot it straight, the rocket will get shot down.

The combat is rich and fulfilling with certain segments of driving such as a boat or car segment where you still get out and go into buildings to combat things. There are also puzzles and challenges to breakup the action just like there were with the original game. It keeps you thinking, sometimes over thinking. There are puzzles such as using a crane to move your car, using a washing machine to weigh down a platform and taking out a force field by rolling a car (trying not to spoil). There are less puzzles in this game than the last, most of the puzzles seem to involve combat like using the gravity gun as a weapon.

Level design is well thought out. Areas are very realistic and cluttered with things you'd really find in any given area. There are trees, junk, wrecked cars, beds, dilapidated walls, broken floors and so on. It really helps the immersion that these areas feel real instead of a typical video game level. This is a very linear game that does have little points of exploration, but you are cleverly guided through things that catch your eye. Like lights in a room are turned on or a character standing under a light and the game will condition you to subtle cues that they mean go here" or characters will flat out say "run Gordon! Go now I'll hold them off."

The game has several new or altered enemies. Even the old enemies are more difficult and altered. There are new head crabs

reviewText:
( I've played all HL games so far in 2016, so no nostalgia involved)
Half-Life 1 was okay/good.  I loved Opposing Forces  even more, and Half-Life 2 overall was even better, with some parts of the game not being that good. At the time of writing this review I haven't played the Episodes, so I don't really know info about them.
The game starts with GMan telling you that there's stuff to do, and driven by free choice Gordon Freeman does whatever he wants, as long as he follows the corridor the game opens to him. Jokes aside, the game is a huge and long corridor. A very pretty and well done, well built corridor, but still, the game lacks choice and freedom - though it's not really a problem, as the game is action-driven, always happens something that forces you to go further. Attack from beind, tunnels collapsing, or they say the next goal is ahead of you.
And here's where one of the things come in the picture that made the game sooo much better for me that HL1 was - change of environment.  HL1 was in Black Mesa and in Xen, and while the two was vastly different, and the level design was great, you still spent most of your time between walls of BM.  On the other hand in HL 2 there are canals, sewers, city landscape, country-like environment, beach, cliffs, a mining town worthy of horror stories, Combine (aliens) base, and street warfare. Not only the level layout changed, but the style as well. Cities had snipers, zombies and headcrabs were abundant in abandoned places, while combine had most power in the city.  So type of the enemies, coupled with the different environments and available weapons at that point made the game really diverse, while it was really consistent, logical by building up that diversity.
Things I loved it in game:
- Finally a proper story with recurring characters, and not just random people telling me where to go and never seeing them again.  Actually the story was really enjoyable.
- Good weapon selection - they are different, and I think all weapons were useful in certain situations. While one can have a favourite weapon, there wasn't useless ones.
- Physics are just awesome. The ragdoll after hitting enemies with the crossbow, how explosions throw stuff around, and how *incredibly* well the gravity gun was implemented in the game. The gravity gun is basically a tech bragging from Valve to show off the physics, but instead of it being a show-weapon, they made lots and lots of situations where it was needed. In modern games a lots of new things are used only for a short period, here the Gravity Gun, the driveable buggy and airboat was used for quite a lot of time, G.G. for the most obviously
- Secrets, AKA Lambda-locations. They are not really useful if you're at least average with FPS games, as they only give ammo, health and ocassionally shields, but they balance out the game for people who are not too good at FPS, but pay attention to their surroundings. I personally love it when a game rewards you for discovery.

And the negative:
- Basically character collision. I finally meet Eli and Alyx, I'm just standing, staring at them talking and then Alyx just pushes me away. In SO MANY scripted moments they just push me away instead of properly avoiding me, and it was really, really annoying and immersion breaking.
-Character collision 2.0:  you and your squad.  I demand the rights to shoot those terrible soldiers who block eachother and me - they follow me, staying behind like 3-5 metres, and any time I have to go back they bump to me, to eachother, they pushes eachother away like domino pieces, and it's just superfun when a strider is shooting at me.
-Preposition? The game's start is really weird in my opinion. Climbing though a fence, going in a random house, then getting chased because... why? The game tries to show the Combine bad, so the player would rather flee from them (as lack of means to fight back) but in the game it's not even explained why they are there, and who they are. Which is really weird for me, and made me question the actions and happenings in the first few chapters.
These are the only things I can't even grasp how they managed to leave in the game, I can't recall anything else more than mildly annoying.
Game is still a lot of fun today, and playing it absolutely made me realize how incredily powerful and useful the engine is, and why there are so many mods based on it - the game is fun:  varied enemies and weapons, there are often some mini-puzzles to solve to go further (like collecting 3 car batteries) make the game still a really enjoyable experience. I would recommend playing it if you want a better gameplay experience than a story  - the story is full with mysteries, but playing the game feels much more rewarding than most newer FPS games proved to be for me.

reviewText:
A near-perfect first person shooter through a convincing, imaginative world filled with believable characters. If you haven't played it already then you should, it holds up well against recent titles and embarrasses a fair few.

The game has so many little touches that make it better than its competitors. The shotgun has a tight blast radius, so it's effective even at considerable distances. The gravity gun gave meaning to the rubbish strewn across the levels. Who would have thought a radiator could serve as a weapon, a shield and a useful platform to reach high-up areas? The grenades are satisfyingly clunky, the explosive barrels are meaty and I wish that they sold bugbait stress balls. It's probably the nicest sounding weapon in the world (and beyond).

This game needs no introduction. It's the game that single-handedly brought Steam onto desktop PCs everywhere. It had to live up to the standards set by the original and it surpassed it in every way. Graphically it was ahead of its time, with detailed character animations and convincing CLUTTER all over the world. Each level leads straight on from the previous so you can almost draw a mental map of City 17 as you journey towards the looming Citadel in the centre. You can see the sun slowly setting as the levels progress and distant sirens and explosions really draw you into the Eastern-European themed city. There's something very lonely about the echo of a gun shot on the cliff levels.

Every chapter has its own theme and alterations to the gameplay. You'll find yourself in vehicles, or battling against a certain type of enemy, or battling WITH that type of enemy against another sort. It really makes me wonder why other developers bother even trying to compete with the creativity that this title offers.

Is it perfect? Nhggghhh, almost. I could say that the vehicle sections go on for a bit too long and the quiet, talky sections (which used to be my favourite- LOOK AT THEIR FACES!) have aged a bit. I find myself hitting things with a crowbar, waiting for more enemies to kill.

Seriously, if you don't enjoy this game then first person shooters aren't for you.

reviewText: A lot can be said about Valve's Half-Life 2. In fact so much has been said that it feels redundant just talking about it. Yeah we all know the games amazing story, and the tight controls, and stunning graphics. I mean JESUS look at those graphics! But what really makes HL2 great, besides just the stuff mentioned? We know its the shining crown jewel of gaming, but do we really know why? The short of it is that the game is extremely solid on all fronts, something that truly can't be said about many games. Everything flows, in a way that AAA games still can't come close to, so much to an extent that I feel people sell Half-Life 2 short, even the people prasing it. Sure games today are made for a wider audience and they get that with shiny graphics and a more streamlined cinematic experience. reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is a very diverse game. Though action-packed, you'll also have moments when you are forced to stop and think... what items do I need and how do I use them to get past this obstacle? Using machinery or sometimes by simply stacking up objects.

In some areas you'll be able to drive in a buggy or hover boat with onboard alien weapons, accompanied by fast-paced music to get your heart pumping. You'll also have to cross some scary areas that you don't want to do just before going to bed.

I love the controls in this game and there's a nice variety of weapons you can use. The story and the great gameplay makes you wanna keep on playing even after you've finished the game.

You can have lots of hours of fun playing through the different difficulty modes. One of my most favorite games, definitely worth to try out!

*Note: At the time of this review I have only played Half-Life 1 and its expansions, along with the base game of Half-Life 2, which I am currently reviewing. I have yet to play the next two episodes that branch off from this game.

Overview Half-Life 2 is hands down the best linearly crafted game I have ever played. Every aspect of this masterpiece has been perfected by the developers, and I really can't stress how well it all comes together. In this review I will go over Half-Life 2's graphics/performance, gameplay, story, and some closing thoughts in order to break down its flawlessness.

Wake up Mr. Freeman, wake up and smell the ashes.

Graphics/Performance It may be just over a decade old, but Half-Life 2 is still a seriously beautiful game. From the textures to the physics, all was designed to the highest fidelity that could possibly be achieved in those times, and then some. The visuals were so ahead of their time in fact, it took another 3 years for any game to catch up to Half-Life 2's graphical prowess, which was the first Crysis game. I really can't see how anyone, even today, can truthfully say Half-Life 2 is outdated aesthetically speaking. Crank all the video settings to max, play in 1080p, easily get 60fps+ and you're in for a scenic experience through a wonderful game. Now, on with the performance. reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is a first-person shooter game from Valve. It is a sequel to the previous game, Half-Life.

The game focus on storyline set after the event of Half-Life, in a City 17 somewhere in Eastern Europe. You play as Gordon Freeman, the protagonist from Half-Life and embark on a new journey as he return from G-man stasis. The world that he once knew has changed, the Combine has taken over. Now he must struggle along with his fellow human resistance for survival.

Using the new Source Engine, Half-Life 2 has remarkable graphics and far better than the previous Half-Life game. The new physics are incredible, almost everything is moveable. Textures and effects are also even more beautiful. The best graphics of the time.

It's a good classic first-person shooter game with the best story, I recommend this.

Rating 10/10

reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is an amazing game.

Half-Life 2's level design is really good and does a good job at letting you be in a confined space but not letting you feel trapped. It feels authentic in a sense that, if you're in a specific level, you're trapped by actual walls or solid and visible objects; as opposed to invisible objects. Some would think that it might have invisible walls with a futuristic touch, like blue lines going through it, since it is a Sci-Fi game.

Half-Life 2 also does an excellent job and making you feel scared. There is one level, Ravenholm, it is absolutely filled with zombies, it is a very dark and eerie level. I remember, the entire time I was playing through it, I was extremely terrified, but had to power through. It was hard.

Half-Life 2's combat is pretty spot on, almost no errors anywhere with hitboxes being fine and no noticeable or game-breaking bugs. The game also has a variety of weapons.

Half-Life 2 lets you drive 2 vehicles in the game, one of which is a Jeep, it is a very fast land-vehicle. It is mildly difficult to control while at high speeds, which isn't a bad thing, it's to be expected. The Airboat is a fast land and water vehicle which is noticeably difficult to control, at almost any time. The game has a good sue of vehicles in specific levels.

Half-Life 2's soundtrack and sounds do sound very modern. The soundtrack is extremely good, and chooses what to play at specific times, but even so, the music it does actually play is very good. Even now, while writing this review, I am listening to part of the soundtrack, Triage at Dawn, it is called. A very, very nice part of the soundtrack. The sounds, even crowbarring a toilet or a wall, do sound very real.

The game, I should talk about, doesn't, for me, at least, do an excellent job at keeping you hooked, it took me a while in between play-sessions to get back into it. But I very recently finished it.

This all makes out to be a very pleasant gaming experience, and it is highly recommended as a game.
91/100

reviewText:
Let's get this out of the way: the Source engine is showing its age â€“ later Valve games have incorporated upgrades that are lacking in Half-Life 2. There isnâ€™t much detail compared to more recent games, textures are blurry, and there are problems with lighting and shadows. All of that is true, but it really isnâ€™t fair to criticize the game for thatâ€¦it was made in 2004, and it looks like it was, but that doesnâ€™t take away from how fun it is to play. And besides, if youâ€™re really concerned about the graphics, you can always download one of the free community mods (Half-Life 2: Update for example) which make it look prettier.

On to my thoughts on the gameplay. I think the reason Half-Life 2 was (and still is) so successful is because the gameplay constantly evolves as you progress forward. As soon as you become comfortable, youâ€™re presented with something which changes how you can approach each situation. After playing the beginning â€“ which feels like a fairly standard shooter â€“ youâ€™re given the airboat and giant arenas to play around with. After a while of that, they give you a machine gun on the airboat, changing up how you use it. Then youâ€™re given the gravity gun, and immediately thrust into Ravenholm, a haunting and creepy environment filled with saw blades, barrels, and other things you can throw at enemies. Then comes the dune buggy and ant-lions, and some of my favorite sections of the game. Traveling down Highway 17, dodging ant-lions as you ferret out combine strongholds on the coast, showcases some of the best that Half-Life 2 has to offer.

But the game isnâ€™t done throwing new things at you. After fighting the ant-lions, youâ€™re given a tool which makes them your allies, and you use them to assault Nova Prospekt, a claustrophobic prison where youâ€™re given access to automated turrets and have to stand your ground against waves of Combine soldiers. Once youâ€™ve escaped Nova Prospekt, youâ€™re thrown into a full-blown rebellion and given command of a squad of resistance fighters. And then finally, at the end of the game, all of your weapons are taken away except for a super-powered gravity gun, and you get to experience what itâ€™s like to throw men around like rag dolls as you rampage through the citadel.

Not all of these are executed perfectly â€“ the squad command sections in particular hilariously showcase the shortcomings of the AI, with companions constantly getting in your way, running out to die from snipers or grenades, and generally acting like morons. Some of the pacing, particularly at the beginning of the game as you run through sewer after sewer and later as you crawl through Nova Prospekt, is tedious and repetitive. But itâ€™s worth playing through those sections to see what comes next, because thereâ€™s always something new around the corner.

Half-Life 2 still does a far better job than most recent games in shifting the gameâ€™s paradigm constantly, and that evolving gameplay makes it successful â€“ and fun to play over a decade later. If itâ€™s been a while since you played it, itâ€™s worth it to revisit it. If youâ€™ve never played it before, it wonâ€™t wow you with its looks, but youâ€™ll experience a classic with some of the best gameplay around â€“ and widely considered one of the best games ever made.

reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is one of those games that everyone has, but not everyone has played. I still get surprised whenever I come across someone who spends a lot of time playing games, but hasn't finished (or even played) Half-Life 2.

The story telling in this game is fantastic. The story, characters and levels are well developed and it's clear just how much time went into making the game. I love all the detail put into level design, character development and design, and voice acting.

Some people think the graphics are a little dated, which is true. It's a game from 2004. But if anything, I think it adds to the feel of the game. Additionally, what game will never have it's graphics dated? Technology changes people, gosh.

If you have Half-Life 2 in your steam library but haven't yet played or are yet to acquire a copy, I strongly recommend giving it a shot. You won't regret it. You'd better be quick though, you'd want to finish it before Half-Life 3 is released!

And of course you've gotta love some ABHing, wall climbing and grenade jumping while speedrunning!

Super highly recommended!
Happy Life Halving!

reviewText:
Ho rigiocato HL2 dopo 10 anni. Ho impiegato 4 giorni a finirlo, contro il mese impiegato 10 anni fa. Questo mi rassicura non poco riguardo alla mia memoria e capacitÃ  di apprendimento, evidentemente non ancora del tutto devastate dall'etÃ ... Il gioco si presenta ancora molto bene, e quando si inizia Ã¨ difficile smettere (un po' come con le sigarette). Certo lo stupore provato la prima volta, per la grafica, la fisica e il gameplay oggi non c'Ã¨ piÃ¹, ma il divertimento Ã¨ comunque ancora assicurato. I percorsi obbligati, gli enigmi mai troppo complicati e le ottime possibilitÃ  di salvataggio rendono il gioco sempre scorrevole e mai frustrante. L'HDR ha reso la grafica ancora piÃ¹ realistica (per un gioco di 10 anni fa, ovviamente). Un po' lenti i caricamenti, e i salvataggi  causano spesso momentanei inceppamenti, particolarmente fastidiosi a livello audio.
Resta in ogni caso un gioco fondamentale, una vera pietra miliare da non perdere assolutamente.

I replayed HL2 after 10 years. It took me four days to finish it, against the month took 10 years ago. That reassures me more than a little about my memory and learning ability, apparently not yet completely devastated by age ... The game is still very good, and when you start it is hard to stop (a bit like with cigarettes). Certainly the astonishment felt the first time, for graphics, physics and gameplay today is no more, but the fun is still yet assured. The obligatory paths, the puzzles never too complicated and very good chances of saving make the game always smooth and never frustrating. The HDR made even more realistic graphics (for a ten years old game, of course). A little slow the loadings, and saving often produced momentary jamming, particularly annoying to hear.
It is in any case a crucial game, a milestone not to be missed.

reviewText: This is one of the few games where you can believe the hype and not be let down in the slightest.  I had been told for YEARS how much of an experience this was but never gave it a shot... reviewText:
Half Life 2 was released in 2004, 6 years after the first one. As i said Half Life revolutionized the FPS genre. Both story wise and gameplay wise. They were the first to do what others dared not to. And guess what? They done it again with it's sequal.

Half Life 2's budget consisted out of $40,000,000. What's revolutionary about this game is the source engine. It provided realistic physics and facial animations.

Story
In the first game a portal opens up from a planet named Xen. You end up destroying the Queen, thus braking the portal link and ending up in captivity of Gman. The events of Half Life 2 happen 20 years after Half Life 1, somewhere in a eastern Europe town called City 17. Human race got enslaved by Combine, an alien race that was in war with Xen, which got interested in Earth after the events of Half Life 1. Gman decides to send you to City 17 to help the resistance.
The realistic facial animations, and graphics in general that source engine provided really add up to the experience. The character really come to life thanks to those facial animations. The game was also filled with action packed cinematic set pieces, as well as unique levels. A zombie town for example. Or a land with arachnid creatures coming out of the sand. The boat chase. Or the one where you have to use the crane to get you car to the other side of the gate. And that final level. Once again, there was no game like it. They were the first to do it.
Back then COD didn't have nukes. There was no David Cage's Fahrenheit/Heavy Rain, or Naughty Dogs's Uncharted/Last of Us. No Telltale's Walking Dead or L.A. Noire. So Bravo!" to Valve.


Gameplay
Thanks to the physics that source provided
date: the new thing about this game is the gravity gun
recommended: which lets you pick up and throw objects. You can pick up sharp objects and cut enemies in half. Or use explosive barrels to lite them up. Or simply smash them with something heavy. reviewText:
Game wise it was an amazing experience & the variety of settings, story driven gameplay + all those little touches that Valve seem to be so good at adding, made it very worthwhile. The graphics are fantastic & the areas in the game often have a kind of gritty realism not seen before in a FPS. City 17 is an amazing backdrop for a game not to mention the surrounding areas such as highway 17, the Nova Prospekt prison complex & especially the citadel which is as alien as Xen but portrayed in a much less organic & much more mechanical Manor. On the whole the HL2 world is an amazing contrast of urban/suburban realism, a variety of outdoor locations & cold alien structures.
HL2 also attempts to build on the character interaction that was revolutionary in the first game. Later in HL2 you will be joined by resistance fighters that form into a small squad that you can control. However you have extremely limited control over this squad. You simply order them to collectively follow you or move to an area that you point out with the crosshair & that's about it.
Everything in HL2 behaves as you would expect it to in the real world & this really helps to draw you into the HL2 world. No more so then when you are first let loose with the gravity gun. This 'weapon' almost turns the game into a glorified physics engine demo but Valve have managed to implement this device in such a way that it becomes indispensable in your quest as well as an awe inspiring tool for demonstrating the physics engine.
The sound in HL2 is a very strong point. Amazing FX, background sounds & music that suits the action & seems to carve a niche of it's own. It's good to see such attention paid to an area which is sometimes overlooked in games & plays second fiddle to the graphics. In HL2 the sound is as important to the feel of the world as the graphics are. Probably some of the best sound I've ever heard in a game. I thought Doom 3's sound was amazing but HL2's is more subtle & as such often more effective.

reviewText:
After many years I finally completed HL2 and its expansions, and really, it's a game that stands out in the FPS genre.

The gameplay is fluid and dynamic, has a satisfactory pace that keeps you stuck to the game and can dose the action sequences with parts that you should play more cautiously, exploring the environment. The AI is a strong point, and although there is little variety of enemies, you don't have a repetitiveness feeling while playing. The Source Engine needs no comments, even after almost 10 years of launching the graphics and physics effects are still convincing. The sound effects are also great.

It's in the plot that the game stands out even more, the story is great and is able to keep you immersed in the storyline like few games can, there is a good dose of mystery about some events and some of the most epic and charismatic characters. Gordon Freeman is arguably the most badass and emblematic protagonist of the gaming world, without even saying a single word. The secondary characters are also well-built and charismatic.

I highly recommend for those who haven't played. In case of not having played the first and its expansions, is good to seek a source with information about the events prior to this title.

9/10

reviewText: In the spirit of it's predecessor, Half-Life 2 was a groundbreaking FPS at the time it was released.  Most notably was it's use of in-game physics.  Many objects (including enemies) can be used to solve various puzzles and used as weapons throughout this experience.  The actual story is somewhat of an enigma, but the path you are driven to follow and the characters you meet along the way make journey enjoyable nonetheless.  I never experienced the feeling that I was killing enemies simply because I had to progress or the play becoming monotonous.  Each chapter, and indeed the many parts of thereof, was composed of a variety of challenges that were easy enough to pick up but not always as easy to execute.  The only con I can come up with is the squad you get at a point in the game and their inability to stay out of your way at times (especially in narrow hallways D:).    This fast-paced shooter belongs in every action gamer's library. Bravo Valve!

reviewText:
More than 9 years old and it's still better than what other FPS games are being churned out today.  Instead of being some elite marine, Gordon Freeman is nothing but a scientist forced to fight for suvival.  And the game plays like that.  Without your Biohazard suit you feel about as useful as any of the other Citizens in the world.

Each level is unique and brings around its own gameplay challenges and puzzles.  Do you stop at that house with the smoke comming from it, or continue without stopping?  It's your choice, you are not expected to defeat every single enemy you come across, you can just simply run away.  Not always though.

The enemy AI is efficient, even if it may cheat somewhat.  They will advance and use cover, use flanking techniques and move as a squad.  It is let down how it seems to know exactly where you are, even after losing line of sight.  Or perhaps the AI is more intelligent than I'm giving it credit for and can hear my footsteps?  Gordon does sound flat footed at times.

The physics engine is still absolutely amazing and well oiled. Need to get over a ledge, but it's too tall?  Good job there is a see-saw next to it, just load the other end with all those bricks lying around to counter balance your weight.  Can't get that draw bridge down, because you are on the wrong side?  No problem, knock it over with that crane.  Ran out of ammo?  Well luckly there is a toilet bowl here and the gravity gun is fully charged.

If there is only one thing to gipe about and I do have only the one.  It's the companion AI.  Wait, just here me out.  It starts out fine, with Alyx, just the one.  She get's in your way a bit now and then.  Nothing too annoying, even though she sticks to you like glue and will follow you down every small dead end ally or single exit room.  She will apologize for being in your way, then move away a bit a moment later.  OK, not too much of a problem.  Then you get 4 companions.  All do the same, all stick to you like glue when going down dead end ally ways and block the exit.  The companions can apologise as much about being in the way they as they can, but it will get infuriating at times.  I was evantually glad when a strider wiped them out in a later mission, with no site of reinforcements.

Voice acting is tremendous and you also form bonds with the main characters.  Helped along with the facials expressions the engine is capable of.  I don't remember seeing another video game where so much detail can be put through via facial expressions to show the emotions of each character.

In closing, Half-Life 2 is a brilliant FPS which hits the right notes in almost every area.  While not a technically impressive as some games released today, the game mechanics are solid and provides an interesting universe and characters to explore.  If you have nether played it, buy it now.  There is no reason to wait for it to go on sale either.

reviewText:
To this day, I still remember playing this game all those years ago on my commodore 64. It still sits on the shelf above my computer, complete with the box, manual and all 11 floppy disks, as a tribute to how great this game is. So, Half life 2, where to begin?

When this game came out in 1988, it made a huge impact on the game industry, because at the time the idea of creating a first person shooter was absurd. Even the original half life wasn't in first person, and that came out on the vic-20. Now, before I say anything else, let me just get this out of the way. This game is old and it shows. Although the developers have done a fantastic job of making it run nice and smooth on modern computers, completely eliminating the constant disk swapping present in the original version, there are still many things that might make the younger gamers hesitant about purchasing this. But enough about that, let's get to the game itself.

This game practically invented the first person shooter genre. Now, anyone familiar with BASIC programming and the commodore 64 can see where I'm going when I say the commodore 64 was a slow system. Like, really slow. Every time you move, the graphics on screen have to be redrawn, which usually takes a second or two. The game is drastically simplified in that the game, instead of featuring open, free roaming environments, works on a grid based, tile-walk system, similar to pokemon or the old bard's tale games. Over the course of the game, you level up, and can choose to increase either your health, stamina or magika, which really allows the player to take the time to craft the kind of characters they want.

Now on to combat. There are three guns in the game, the pistol, the shotgun, and the SMG. It's up to you to discover their individual strengths and weaknesses in order to get through the loading screens in one piece. Just remember: Ammo is a precious resource, and must be used only when you truly need it.

Concerning the story, it is definately one of the most finely crafted tales ever woven. Beautiful writing. Unfortunately though, you'll still have to download the paragraph book from the half life website, because when the game was first released, they didn't have the data storage to include all that text in the game.

In conclusion: This game is still a classic, and holds up even today. It is truly sad that the new generations will turn the other cheek at this game and walk away, but in my humble and biased opinion, I give it a buy.

The problem as it is written is 6Ã·2(1+2) , the Ã· cannot be substituted with a fraction bar because they have different ranks on the order of operations. It is an illegal math move to do this. The bar ranks with parentheses, Ã· is interchangeable with *. therefore the problem must be solved as 6Ã·2(1+2) NOT 6 (over) 2(1+2) we do the parentheses first, so 6Ã·2(3), the parentheses are now no longer relevant, because the number inside is in it's simplest form. Every single number has implied parentheses around it.

reviewText:
I recently finished this game, after playing the first one and the expansion packs. I already called Half-Life 1 one of the best games i've ever played, but this one is my all-time favourite.

The game is not even nearly perfect, it is perfect. It's action packed, it got GREAT graphics, animations and more for a game from 2004 and it even got moments which were truly epic.

Unlike the first one, this one offers more puzzles, greater and more evoirments and more action and even a little bit of horror in it. You not only fight against one enemy, no you get to fight headcrabs, helicopters, City 17 Guards, zombies and more. You kill them on your own creative way around the middle of the game when you get more weapons like the Gravity gun, one of my favourites. It let you travel to so many cool area's and not only on foot.. You get to travel to there with for example a car. Absolutly amazing. It's one of the few games of 2004 that offered so many beatiful content and realistic fighting. For example, around the end of the game, you get to control rebels against City 17, they help you, and give you health if needed. Sure, it got it's bugs, sometimes it also brought me motion sickness.. But that didin't stopped me from playing it.

The ending and the mysterious G-Man makes me wanna' play Episode 1, which i surely will. It's only 9 bucks, so if you want to spent that money on a epic journey with enough replay valaue, then go ahead. Buy this game, a game which i think, never gets old and always will stay one of a kind.

Great job Valve, this is one of your games to be proud of.

reviewText: A must-have for PC gamers. While Half-Life 1 most certainly hasn't stood against the test of time, Half-Life 2 has aged like fine wine. Even ten years after it's release, the game looks and feels good. Playing as the mute Gordon Freeman, who arrives off the train in City 17, discovers that the city has been taken over by a force only known as the Combine. Shortly after, he meets the protagonists of the game. If I have to make a complaint, it's that none of the characters in Half-Life 2 besides Gordon and the Gman were in Half-Life 1, so you're just supposed to assume that they were there during the Black Mesa incident. To fully understand the story of Half-Life 1, all you have to do is watch the first ten minutes and the last five minutes of the game. I suggest that you skip straight to this one, and if you really want to pick up Half-Life 1 make sure it's less than $5.

reviewText:
Because you see what happened after Black Mesa, because you want Alyx and because it's the sequel of one of the best FPS in the world.

Half-Life 2 is simply set in a world post-Black Mesa, where an entity known as the Combine took control of the Earth, thanks to Dr. Breen, your ex-boss, that negociated the peace. And what peace! Police is brutal, resistance fighters are sent to their death in Nova Prospekt or bombed with Headcrabs missiles, the extinction of mankind is planned as no children can be conceived because of a force field suppressor and Dr. Kleiner, your mentor, has as pet an Headcrab (which is a sort of disaster for your buddy Barney Calhoun.

The gameplay is still the same: you shoot, you kill and you try to stay alive between Headcrabs, Antlions and Combine units. And with your arsenal (bazooka, smg, shotgun, crowbar, antlion stuff, crossbow, etc..), you'll be well equipped. The Gravity Gun is also THE new feature: you can take items and throw them or just carry them. And you'll love the Super Gravity Gun at the end of the game.

The story will make you visit City 17 before and during the battle for freedom, you'll also take an escape road but very dangerous, see what happens when a town is bombed with missiles, meet a crazy priest, go to the beach, break into a high-security prison and even meet Dr Breen in person. The settings are varied, now that you're outside of Black Mesa and the scientific environement.

The new enemies are the Combine Army, kinda replacing the HECU units sent to Black Mesa, but with a better technology, the Antlions, a new alien race, that will be your allies and new types of zombies due to new headcrabs: a faster one and a poisonous one. You can set them in fire too.

You'll ride also a buggy and a hydroboat, which is changing from the wagon cart from Black Mesa.

Otherwise, the allies will be resistance fighters with their chiefs like Eli, Alyx or Barney, though Alyx will be more your sidekick by moments than Barney. Also, the Vortigaunts, these aliens from Xen with green rays, freed from their enslavement, can assist you and recharge your protection.

With the Source Engine, Valve managed to get beautiful graphics but also, good physics, thanks to the Gravity Gun being the new toy for many players.

And the soundtrack! It's still marvelous. Still feeling danger or sad moments or adrenaline.

Half-Life 2 can be seen as perfect in every aspect... apart the loading time. Or the fact that achievements got implemented at a late date after the release of the Orange Box on Steam (X-box owners had achievements in 2007, PC players got them finally in 2010).

Anyway, fun, drama and action are present and Half-Life 2 is really a must-have.

reviewText:
Yes, I would like to start this review by saying that this is my second favorite FPS game. That is not say that it is in the second place because it is almost impossible to choose between Half-Life and Half-Life 2. And that would be unfair as well. These games are from different centuries but both are great, equally great. So what makes is so great? Let's find out...

First and foremost I'm absolutely blown away by the story. Maybe not by the story itself but by the way it's told. The first game made me feel in the center of attention and action. It felt like it was very important to complete the mission but without making me feeling some sort of superhero that will win anyway. It may sound strange but I can't better words for it. And it continues here with one of the best intros I have seen in a game. Do you remember how the first game ended? Yes, it ended with a monologue of a man in a blue suit after which you agreed to work for him without really knowing who is working for. This game start with another monologue saying that the time has come for you to unleash all your skills and complete another very tall task. It all feels amazingly tense and even though you're ready to spring into action you are not a superhero so don't expect being handed a machinegun and go around shooting.

As I said the narrative is outstanding throughout the game series and it makes it feel very realistic and natural. I donâ€™t want to spoil it for you so I'll let you see it for yourself. What I can tell you though is the way I felt when I started playing. Let's continue then, shall we?
So you awake several years after the end of the first part. It is somewhere in the eastern Europe from what I can tell by the architecture, well by what is left from it. The atmosphere is very grim and depressing and you're alone in a unfamiliar city trying to figure out what you need to do and if there are any friends of yours. The first thing you notice are the screens with propaganda and giant tower that you can see from any part of the city. And all of that really put me in the mood to fight. Because clearly someone is controlling the city and most likely the earth.
All of that is backed up by incredible ambient sounds and music. I don't know if it really makes sense to talk about music in this game but if you read review on the original game you'll know that it is something. It follows you around submerges you entirely into everything that is happening around. I first played the game in headphones and that was very wise decision and I'd recommend that to you as well.

What kind of atmosphere can be there without proper visuals. And graphics are certainly there. And not just any graphics. Probably the best for the time. For me that is. But considering that it has been more than 10 years since the release of the game you could argue. But if you're into more realistic visuals you can find a mod online that will turn the game into eyecandy.

So this game has amazing sounds, graphics and story. How does it play then. Well, it pays absolutely fantastic. It is a true sequel and it carried over everything that made the original such a great game. Suit is there, crowbar is there, awesome guns are there to accompany dynamic and fast-paced shooting action. Even if you're not shooting you can still feel the adrenaline. Guns are fantastic to use, blasting through the enemies. And there's variety of enemies ranging from headcrabs to helicopters and giant striders. All of them have very good AI and they never made me feel an overpowered protagonist putting down handicapped enemies. It's complete opposite because I found myself many times low on ammo and low on health hearing suit AI saying User death imminent". What Half-Life never lacked are the unusual weapons and you'll some this time as well. For example Pulse Rifle which is my favorite and something very special - Gravity Gun. The latter really helps to get out of sticky situations when you're low on ammo or being overpowered by zombies. It has so many uses and every time I figured out something new I felt real scientist. By the way this time you're not doing everything alone. You have friends that will aid in the battle. I would characterize their AI as limited but sometimes they are really helpful. In my opinion their role is to make you feel as a part of Resistance more than anything else. And they certainly succeed at that.

You will come across quite a few puzzles. What would Half-Life game be without puzzles. They are not that hard but require you to see the big picture. Gordon Freeman went to MIT so those puzzles should be not a problem.

As with the original game I played Half-Life 2 more than once. I played few times just didn't feel like playing something else and then I played it once again to unlock every single achievement and then I played it prior to Episode One and Two to refresh memories
This game is definitely worth picking up even though it's more than 10 years old but it still has that tense
recommended: immersive music and graphics that hold up today in my opinion.\n\nMore reviews from Gameaways Curator"

reviewText:
Video Playthrough
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MUCpiUOdj8o

This is the follow up to the masterpiece that was the original Half-Life.

This game has a beautiful story, amazing graphics, great A.I. which is still rare to see in games even today.

You'll have a vast array of weapons that you'll pick up throughout the game, each of them feeling unique with, damage, range, effects and occasionally secondary fire.

Driving sequences are fun and smooth to play.

The game is full of memorable characters. Both good and evil.

Synopsis: You are Gordon Freeman, a scientist that worked at the Black Mesa Research Facility, You've just been awoken from stasis by the G-man, after the 7 hour war between the human resistance and the Combine. You'll meet up with new and old characters alike and try to take the earth back from the Combine.

If you still haven't played this game, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Half-Life 2. The video game that started the modern generation on first-person shooters and revamped the gaming history into a new era. Originally released in November 2004, the game won multiple game of the year awards and branched gameplay mechanics, including physics and the state-of-the-art game engine that look realistic during its release date. Many people are aware on the gameâ€™s popularity and everlasting legacy including various jokes on the awaiting sequel (for many years), but the question remains: Why is this game popular?

The game takes place after the events from Half-Life. You play as Gordon Freeman, the silent protagonist who got a Ph.D. on theoretical physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and knows how to use weapons very effectively; a strange paradox for a character with such features yet highly popular and well-recognized. You are sent to City 17 by the G-Man, a mysterious person or a phenomenon with a mysterious and ambiguous agenda, to overthrow Wallace Breen and the alien oppressors, the Combine. The setting and lore in the Half-Life universe is simply the best, taking some influence from George Orwellâ€™s 1984 or other famous dystopian novels to set the story in tone. Gordonâ€™s influence and previous actions will spark oppressed citizens in City 17 to take arms and revolt against the Combine. From City 17 to the prison at Nova Prospekt, each setting is unique, bleak, but beautifully designed, the game simply defined what a video game should be.

Each NPCs and major characters such as Doctor Issac Kleiner, Barney Calhoun, and other characters interact realistically among each other and to you. In regards to Alyx Vance, your ally and companion, Valve spawned the concept of AI teammates and became a true asset in your journey to rally up the oppressed citizens. Besides good character developments, the best attribute for Half-Life 2 was physic interactions and the game engine. The game engine is Source, which feature high-dynamic range rendering, facial animations, and â€œrealistic physicsâ€; the first game that had such a feature like this.

Are there criticisms for the game? I believe so, but to be honest, I couldnâ€™t find any legitimate criticisms for the game. If one criticism has to be addressed, then the problem is the loading sections. Yes, those tedious loading that interrupted the â€œflowâ€ in the middle of a long level or after finishing a series of firefights against Civil Protection or Combine forces. These loading or â€œcheckpointsâ€ really halt the immersion in the game. However, this is very common on all Half-Life games and I hope that Valve would address this (if they are working on the sequelâ€¦).

Half-Life 2 is pure gold, shining flawlessly on the test of time. With great graphical fidelity at its time, voice acting and realistic AI interaction from your allies and enemies, this game is a rare exception of genuine perfection and grand role model for other game developers to pursue their own game designs. The only thing Half-Life 2 (and its episodes) is a full fledge sequel. Besides many jokes, anxieties, and waning patience for Valve to announce the sequel, the game should be in every PC gamerâ€™s Steam library. No exception. Half-Life 2 is simply the best; a grand overture that started and defined the modern gaming industry in the present time.

reviewText: This is simply the best game ever made. 10 years after release, and no other game has surpassed it yet. The atmosphere, characters and Source engine were all, putting it mildly, revolutionary at the time. They all still hold up well today. Not to mention it CHANGED THE GAMING INDUSTRY, even more so than Half-Life 1 did. Think about it. Without HL2, Steam would probably be dead, in which case thousands of indie games would've never been made, let alone gain as much popularity, forcing all those indie developers to stop making games. Without HL2, Valve probably wouldn't have made their other masterpieces (Portal, TF2, L4D, etc.) Without HL2, and its amazing mod support, we wouldn't have gotten the best modding community ever in gaming.\nThere are too many good things to say about Half-Life 2, so I'll make a long review short:\nBuy it. Buy it now. Just make sure you play Half-Life 1 beforehand obviously.

I highly recommend this game if you don't already have it.  Seriously.  This game is different from other games.  It just felt right when I played this.

reviewText:
Sequel of one of the highest acclaimed games of all time. Half-Life continues the story of Gordon Freeman as he is woken up only to find that Earth has been taken over by an alien empire - the Combine. Throughout the game, he gets help from human resistance and former allies from Black Mesa.

Puzzles are pretty much kept at the first installation's style, though I found them to be way easier. In Half-Life 2, there are more vehicles - an airboat and a buggy are added and they provide some more refreshing gameplay where you drive with them and ocassionally have to stop in order to solve a puzzle, because the path is blocked.

Game features more weapons, most importantly - the gravity gun. I guess it shows the psychics of the source engine, but its a pretty fun weapon to use, some areas can be cleared without using any firearms. Near the end of the game it becomes even better and more powerful.

Obviously, it has better graphics than Half-Life 1.

For those that liked the first game - this is a must buy. I guess you can still play it as your first game from the franchise, but it just isn't the same in my opinion.

reviewText:
Half Life 2 - One of the most anticipated sequels of all time.

How exactly do you follow up one of the greatest first person shooters of all time? By making an even better first person shooter! With it's fully upgraded graphics, and an entire new engine, Half Life 2 makes the wait worth it. Dive into a world controlled by an organisation lead by a power hungry overseer. You are Gordon Freeman, the silent hero. Take Gordon from a simple train journey, into a war that will take place on beachheads, on cliff faces, even in abondoned mining towns, and along the way fight humans and aliens alike.

You will be instantly hooked on this game, with a storyline that does not disappoint to accompany breathtaking graphics and music.

reviewText:
The epitome of the perfect modern FPS.

With visuals that still stand up, AI smarter then your average CoD (They even move to face you when their talking to you, CoD doesn't have that!) some really memorable moments, high adrenaline action, some nice vehicle sections - This game has it all.

The story picks up after the first Half Life Trilogy, Gordon has been reawakened by the ever mysterious G-Man and Gordon is needed once again to help save everyone.

Through City 17 all the way up the Citiadel the story is tight, and the action and gameplay fun.

For me, there was never a moment that I was bored.

And similar to HL1 the puzzles were difficult, but not too difficult because of Valve and how they place objects and light and other entites in relation to eachother that subtely cue you in.

Overall, the perfect modern shooter that holds up 8 years later.

At the time of release it was groundbreaking and almost a decade later there are still few FPS out there that can stand up to it. reviewText:
In some ways, this is a very old-fashioned FPS.  You have a variety of weapons, but can only hold so much ammo.   When you pick up stuff (by touching it), it adds those bullets/health to your supplies if you have any missing, and any excess is lost.  Carrying around health packs/extra ammo is impossible.  You still progress through a bunch of areas, needing to press the right button or trigger the right event to proceed.
What sets it apart is the obvious polish, quality design, and good story.  The game uses only in-engine cinematics, and never takes over the player's camera.  It counts on you to observe the world around you, take an interest in the environment, and solve the various physics puzzles.

Instead of just a bunch of corridors and enemies (though it has those, too), it focuses on small engagements, then big set-piece battles.  You'll play for a while in one setting on foot, then switch to a more vehicle-oriented bit, then a new mechanic is introduced, then it kind of repeats those 3, etc.  This varies up the gameplay and keeps introducing fresh concepts through little in-game tutorials.

About the only complaint I had is that the game wants you to be immersed in its world, and use their impressive physics engine to solve puzzles.  It wants you to approach the obstacles as if you were actually there, making use of the objects around you to get past them.  This is great when it works, like making use of plastic barrels' buoyancy to get past one spot, but then you get to points where you try out a solution over and over, convinced it should be working, and it won't.  Oh, it should work, because it seems obvious, and because it totally would work in the real world, but in the game they want you to do something else pre-scripted, and until you figure out what that thing is, you're not going anywhere.  They make you stack boxes & crates in several spots to climb up/over things, but try it in the wrong place and you'll hit an invisible wall.  There's one area where you have to get past an electric fence and can see the power cable running above you.  Even though you've got a way to hurl nice big, sharp, wide saw blades with great speed and accuracy, you can't sever that cable.  No amount of shooting will help, either.  That cable's not a solid object, it's just there to let you know where to go to hit the switch that you need to find in order to turn off the fence.
Despite a few tired elements and some minor breaks in the immersion, this is one hell of a game.

reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is without a doubt one of the greatest games I have ever played in my life. I have no problem saying that it is my number one favorite. Even today, the physics engine is extraordinary and is still being used in games today. An entire generation of game making, mod making, and even short films was all born from this one game, and that still blows my mind.

The story is just as intense as a Hollywood movie. You care about the characters and you really want to help your allies and strike down your enemies. It is an incredibly immersive experience. Story wise, the entire Half-Life franchise (especially this installment) make it the best video game franchise in history. Despite what some people say, this game has aged incredibly well. There will be more games in the future, some incredible and some horrible. Maybe the magic of Half-Life 2 will be matched, but I personally believe it will never be exceeded.

I loved this game in every respect. Gameplay, graphics, and story is all 10/10.

reviewText:
I don't think anyone really needs to read my drip of a review in the already thriving ocean of love that Half-Life is swimming in, but I'm bored, and you're here.

Half-Life 2 improves upon Valve's amazing storytelling sans-cutscenes and through environmental cues and wonderful voice acting in its NPCs. You are still Gordon Freeman and still as silent as ever, soaking it all in. Some say that he is an empty husk devoid of character, while others treat his silence as an opportunity to let themselves react to the events in the world around them rather than being told how Gordon feels; YOU are Gordon Freeman.

The Source engine was debuted in HL2 and there are many little physics 'puzzles', to use the word generously, that show off the engine's bells and whistles. The gravity gun is really where it shines though.
The AI is competent (any veteran FPS player will have to play on the hardest difficulty setting), and there are many wonderful action set-pieces in well-fleshed out locales.

That's about all I can say here; I may share my thoughts on Episodes 1 and 2 at a later date.
Until then, happy headcrab hunting.

reviewText:
Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 is a single-player first-person shooter broken into several chapters, permanently casting the player as the protagonist Gordon Freeman.
The sequel has nearly the same mechanics as Half-Life, including health-and-weapon systems and periodic physics puzzles, except with the newer Source Engine and improved graphics. The player also starts without items, slowly building up an arsenal over the course of the game. Despite the game's mainly linear nature, much effort was put into making exploration rewarding and interesting; many optional areas can be missed or avoided.

A diverse set of enemies are present, which usually require being approached with different tactics: some coordinate in groups to out-maneuver or out-position the player; others, like the Manhack, fly directly at the player through small openings and tight corridors; some use predictable but powerful attacks, while others hide before swiftly attacking the player. Gordon can kill most enemies with his weapons, or make use of indirect means, exploiting environmental hazards such as explosive pressurized canisters, gas fires or improvised traps. At one point in the game, Gordon can be joined by up to four armed Resistance soldiers, and can send his team further from him or call them back; however, they can still die easily due to lack of damage protection. Squad members are indicated on the HUD (squad member icons with a cross sign are field medics).

Many of the game's new features utilize its detailed physics simulation. Two sections of the game involve driving vehicles. Instead of button-based puzzles from Half-Life, environmental puzzles are also introduced with makeshift mechanical systems, revolving around the player's new ability to pick up, move, and place objects. Solutions involve objects' physical properties, such as shape, weight, and buoyancy. For example, in Chapter 3, Route Kanal, the player is required to stack cinder blocks on a makeshift see-saw ramp to proceed over a wall.

Part-way through the game, Gordon acquires the Gravity Gun, which allows him to draw distant objects towards himself or forcefully push them away, as well as to manipulate larger and heavier objects than he is able to alone. These abilities are required to solve puzzles later in the game, and can also be used to great effect in combat, as any non-static object within proximity to the player has the potential to be used as a makeshift defense (e.g. a file cabinet) or a deadly projectile (e.g. a gasoline can or a buzzsaw blade).

The game never separates the player with pre-rendered cutscenes or events; the story proceeds via exposition from other characters and in-world events, and ensures that the player controls Gordon for the entirety of the game. Much of the backstory to the game is simply alluded to, or told through the environment.

Source; http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Half_life_2

Half Life is one of the first PC games I owned.  I had it when I plugged a power cable into a lan card and fried it.  Oh young dumb PC accidents.  Half Life 2 is a build upon an already amazing franchise.  One that spawned Counter-Strike and Day of Defeat from free Half Life mods to actual stand alone games that were sold in stores.  Half Life 2 is an incredible game with stunning graphics and great AI - for its time.

The gameplay is fun and with the use of Developer Mode, players that are playing the game through for a second, third, or fourth time can enable fun gravity settings or thousands of other commands.  The story line in the game itself is the classic FPS Hero vs The World.

I would rate this game a 9.2/10 because it is still a classic, a benchmark to gaming, a sequel to one of the best games ever made and still one of the highest META rated games in the world.  Half Life 2 is worth the few dollars to purchase - as well as all of the other Valve titles.

reviewText:
The greatest FPS fps of all time. It may not be some heavily gameplay design focused super polished masterpiece like Doom. However the atmosphere, the characters, the physics and environment interaction that still hold up, every big to subtle tid bit of detail where you can tell they poured every ounce of talent and soul into, it all just comes together to make one of the most profound video games ever made. Not to say the gameplay isn't special, for being the game series that sort of set off the whole trend of a more linear focused level design punctuated by amazing scripted events, the gameplay is still miles ahead of most modern FPS games today that do the same thing. One of the things that captures me the most about this game is the absolute sheer amount of variation of different situations this game throws at you. The game absolutely never gets repetitive at all, the game always tosses situations at you that you never really have done beforehand in the game. The fact that the game still captures that feeling of immersion without ever having to sacrifice that feeling in order to make the level design gameplay oriented is just amazing.

I could go on but I don't really think too many people would read this, and everyone already knows how good this game is. All I can say is that it gives off that feeling of wonder and detail, of a full emotional yet functional and fun experience, like no other game before or after yet.
