reviewText:
I can't truly explain why I love this game as much as I do, but to me, it is a work of art. The graphics are outdated for sure, but they work together in a way that negates any low resolution! I love the story. There is little exposition, and you're really thrown into a world that doesn't give a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ if you pay attention to it or not.
There are countless little details you can find with each new playthrough, and they all make the game feel so much more alive! Physics puzzels can get annoying at times, and I don't recommend stacking barrels to ANYONE who wants to retain their sanity, but the atmosphere and story more than make up for it.

The people ingame feel like real people, even though only about 5-6 of them are really CHARACTERS. The generic people in the world still feel like people, and they say people things, they DO people things! Only a stupid physics puzzle has ever broken my immersion in this game. I love it, and I do believe about half the internet agrees with me.

reviewText:
There are a lot of video games out there. From shooters, to racers, to RPG's to RTS's... It has never been a better time to be a gamer nowadays. The choice we have as gamers is overwhelming, and even though there are a lot of flawed products out there, a lot of great titles make their way into our libraries on an yearly basis. As I see it, video games are divided into three categories: Bad, Decent, and Great, from worse to best.
But some games are so unique, different and so many light years ahead of everything else, they don't quite fall under any kind of category. I know a few of these games myself. Half Life 2 is also light years ahead of those games.

Half Life 2 is an experience. It's almost movie like in it's immersion. I found myself caring about the protagonist, Gordon Freeman, my allies Alyx and Eli Vance, Dr Mossman and Dr K, in the fight against the fascist alien race known as the combine. I found myself caring about every little detail of what happened to them, and to my surprise, I have never felt this happy, sad and angry while playing a video game. It truly is an experience.

I won't spoil the story to anyone, but it is by far, and in my opinion, the best story ever put into the video game form, for what it tells you, for what you have to figure out for yourself, and for the most intriguing and misterious character to ever grace a PC game (or any game for that matter): The G-man. When you play this game, you will know exactly what I am talking about.

Gameplay is varied, and the controls are close to perfection. You will walk and shoot like an FPS, drive a boat and buggy. The common link between them is the fact they are seamless and feel like you are on a true quest, no section is out of place and they are all extremely well done. The concept of levels isn't quite present, as the game world feels like a whole.

Half life 2 is an amazing accomplishment. It is the proof that games can be art, and can rival Hollywood in story telling. Make no mistake, Half Life 2 is in my opinion, the best game ever made, and worth every penny and minute you put into it. It is a rewarding experience like no other, and there are almost no games who can even compare to it. A timeless masterpiece.

The Good

Extremely fun to play
Groundbreaking story
Enemy AI
Shooting mechanics
Varied gameplay

The Bad

Nothing I can think of, it really is that good, and as close to perfection as you will ever get.

10/10 - Legendary

reviewText:
It was all in that moment when I just sat back and laughed. I couldn't believe it was quite this good. I chuckled in muddled disbelief, expectations utterly defied. My nervous fingers reloaded the level, knowing that I had to see that breathtaking sequence one more time. It was then that I knew for certain: Valve had surpassed not only themselves, but everyone else too. Half-Life 2 is an astounding accomplishment. It is the definitive statement of the last five years of first-person shooters. Everything else was just a stopgap.

Half-Life 2 is a near perfect sequel. It takes almost everything that worked from Half-Life and either improves on it, or keeps it much the same. But that simple summation undersells how the Valve team have approached this task. Half-Life 2 is a linear shooter with most of the refinements one would expect from years of work, but it is also a game of a higher order of magnitude than any of the previous pretenders to the throne. The polish and the stratospheric height of the production values mean that Half-Life 2 is a magnificent, dramatic experience that has few peers.

It would be madness for me to spoil this game by talking about the specific turn of events, so spoilers are going to be kept to a minimum. We're going to talk about general processes and the elements of style and design that make Half-Life 2 such an energising experience. Key to this is the way in which Gordon's tale is told. Once again we never leave his perspective. There are no cutscenes, no moment in which you are anything but utterly embedded in Gordon's view of the world. Everything is told through his eyes. And what a story it is. Gordon arrives at the central station at City 17â€”a disruptive and chilling dystopia. And from there? Well, that would be telling. This is not the contemporary America that Gordon seemed to be living in during the original Half-Life. The events of Black Mesa have affected the whole world. The crossover with Xen has meant that things have altered radically, with hyper-technology existing alongside eastern bloc dereliction.

reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is without a doubt one of the greatest games I have ever played in my life. I have no problem saying that it is my number one favorite. Even today, the physics engine is extraordinary and is still being used in games today. An entire generation of game making, mod making, and even short films was all born from this one game, and that still blows my mind.

The story is just as intense as a Hollywood movie. You care about the characters and you really want to help your allies and strike down your enemies. It is an incredibly immersive experience. Story wise, the entire Half-Life franchise (especially this installment) make it the best video game franchise in history. Despite what some people say, this game has aged incredibly well. There will be more games in the future, some incredible and some horrible. Maybe the magic of Half-Life 2 will be matched, but I personally believe it will never be exceeded.

I loved this game in every respect. Gameplay, graphics, and story is all 10/10.

reviewText:
Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 is a single-player first-person shooter broken into several chapters, permanently casting the player as the protagonist Gordon Freeman.
The sequel has nearly the same mechanics as Half-Life, including health-and-weapon systems and periodic physics puzzles, except with the newer Source Engine and improved graphics. The player also starts without items, slowly building up an arsenal over the course of the game. Despite the game's mainly linear nature, much effort was put into making exploration rewarding and interesting; many optional areas can be missed or avoided.

A diverse set of enemies are present, which usually require being approached with different tactics: some coordinate in groups to out-maneuver or out-position the player; others, like the Manhack, fly directly at the player through small openings and tight corridors; some use predictable but powerful attacks, while others hide before swiftly attacking the player. Gordon can kill most enemies with his weapons, or make use of indirect means, exploiting environmental hazards such as explosive pressurized canisters, gas fires or improvised traps. At one point in the game, Gordon can be joined by up to four armed Resistance soldiers, and can send his team further from him or call them back; however, they can still die easily due to lack of damage protection. Squad members are indicated on the HUD (squad member icons with a cross sign are field medics).

Many of the game's new features utilize its detailed physics simulation. Two sections of the game involve driving vehicles. Instead of button-based puzzles from Half-Life, environmental puzzles are also introduced with makeshift mechanical systems, revolving around the player's new ability to pick up, move, and place objects. Solutions involve objects' physical properties, such as shape, weight, and buoyancy. For example, in Chapter 3, Route Kanal, the player is required to stack cinder blocks on a makeshift see-saw ramp to proceed over a wall.

Part-way through the game, Gordon acquires the Gravity Gun, which allows him to draw distant objects towards himself or forcefully push them away, as well as to manipulate larger and heavier objects than he is able to alone. These abilities are required to solve puzzles later in the game, and can also be used to great effect in combat, as any non-static object within proximity to the player has the potential to be used as a makeshift defense (e.g. a file cabinet) or a deadly projectile (e.g. a gasoline can or a buzzsaw blade).

The game never separates the player with pre-rendered cutscenes or events; the story proceeds via exposition from other characters and in-world events, and ensures that the player controls Gordon for the entirety of the game. Much of the backstory to the game is simply alluded to, or told through the environment.

reviewText:
HALF LIFE 2 REVIEW

Half Life 2 is the first FPS I ever played. I remember when I bought the Orange Box on PS3 I was just amazed! 5 years later replaying it on PC it just adds to the amazing quality of the game. I loved every single second of it and is one my most favorite games of all time. Half Life 2 is a tense, thrilling, and all around amazing game that should be played by everyone.

NOT FOR: People who don't like FPS's. I would still recommend trying it out, but if that's not really your thing, I don't think Half Life 2 would change your mind all that much. However keep in mind that this is more of an old school first person shooter, unlike say Call of Duty. This game doesn't tell you where to go or how to get there, maybe not as much as the original Half-Life, but still a far cry from the crazy hand holding a lot of modern games have today.

FOR: People who want to play or try out a different stlye of FPS. This is not Call of Duty. No constant checkpoints or arrows showing you where to go. While this may prove frustrating for some...(It was for me the first time I tried it.) It proves to be extremely rewarding. On a other note this game doesn't have regenerating health which up's the challenge factor considerably. Even on easy you can every easily die if you don't react fast enough.

IN CONCLUSION: I hope this review finds you well and if you want some other games like Half Life 2, make sure to get it's sequels Episode 1 & 2 . Also try out Portal and Portal 2 as they are in the same universe. (The Portal series is a puzzle game so it's different, but it's in the same story universe.)  Lastly play the originaly it'll be worth it.

reviewText:
There are a lot of video games out there. From shooters, to racers, to RPG's to RTS's... It has never been a better time to be a gamer nowadays. The choice we have as gamers is overwhelming, and even though there are a lot of flawed products out there, a lot of great titles make their way into our libraries on an yearly basis. As I see it, video games are divided into three categories: Bad, Decent, and Great, from worse to best.
But some games are so unique, different and so many light years ahead of everything else, they don't quite fall under any kind of category. I know a few of these games myself. Half Life 2 is also light years ahead of those games.

Half Life 2 is an experience. It's almost movie like in it's immersion. I found myself caring about the protagonist, Gordon Freeman, my allies Alyx and Eli Vance, Dr Mossman and Dr K, in the fight against the fascist alien race known as the combine. I found myself caring about every little detail of what happened to them, and to my surprise, I have never felt this happy, sad and angry while playing a video game. It truly is an experience.

I won't spoil the story to anyone, but it is by far, and in my opinion, the best story ever put into the video game form, for what it tells you, for what you have to figure out for yourself, and for the most intriguing and misterious character to ever grace a PC game (or any game for that matter): The G-man. When you play this game, you will know exactly what I am talking about.

Gameplay is varied, and the controls are close to perfection. You will walk and shoot like an FPS, drive a boat and buggy. The common link between them is the fact they are seamless and feel like you are on a true quest, no section is out of place and they are all extremely well done. The concept of levels isn't quite present, as the game world feels like a whole.

Half life 2 is an amazing accomplishment. It is the proof that games can be art, and can rival Hollywood in story telling. Make no mistake, Half Life 2 is in my opinion, the best game ever made, and worth every penny and minute you put into it. It is a rewarding experience like no other, and there are almost no games who can even compare to it. A timeless masterpiece.

The Good

Extremely fun to play
Groundbreaking story
Enemy AI
Shooting mechanics
Varied gameplay

The Bad

Nothing I can think of, it really is that good, and as close to perfection as you will ever get.

10/10 - Legendary

reviewText:
In some ways, this is a very old-fashioned FPS.  You have a variety of weapons, but can only hold so much ammo.   When you pick up stuff (by touching it), it adds those bullets/health to your supplies if you have any missing, and any excess is lost.  Carrying around health packs/extra ammo is impossible.  You still progress through a bunch of areas, needing to press the right button or trigger the right event to proceed.
What sets it apart is the obvious polish, quality design, and good story.  The game uses only in-engine cinematics, and never takes over the player's camera.  It counts on you to observe the world around you, take an interest in the environment, and solve the various physics puzzles.

Instead of just a bunch of corridors and enemies (though it has those, too), it focuses on small engagements, then big set-piece battles.  You'll play for a while in one setting on foot, then switch to a more vehicle-oriented bit, then a new mechanic is introduced, then it kind of repeats those 3, etc.  This varies up the gameplay and keeps introducing fresh concepts through little in-game tutorials.

About the only complaint I had is that the game wants you to be immersed in its world, and use their impressive physics engine to solve puzzles.  It wants you to approach the obstacles as if you were actually there, making use of the objects around you to get past them.  This is great when it works, like making use of plastic barrels' buoyancy to get past one spot, but then you get to points where you try out a solution over and over, convinced it should be working, and it won't.  Oh, it should work, because it seems obvious, and because it totally would work in the real world, but in the game they want you to do something else pre-scripted, and until you figure out what that thing is, you're not going anywhere.  They make you stack boxes & crates in several spots to climb up/over things, but try it in the wrong place and you'll hit an invisible wall.  There's one area where you have to get past an electric fence and can see the power cable running above you.  Even though you've got a way to hurl nice big, sharp, wide saw blades with great speed and accuracy, you can't sever that cable.  No amount of shooting will help, either.  That cable's not a solid object, it's just there to let you know where to go to hit the switch that you need to find in order to turn off the fence.
Despite a few tired elements and some minor breaks in the immersion, this is one hell of a game.

reviewText:
Half-Life 2 is a fun, exciting sequel to the 1998 game Half-Life.

In case you skipped the original Half-Life and went on to Half-Life 2, in HL2, you are protagonist Gordon Freeman, a scientist trying to stop the corrupt combines in City 17 from destroying all of humanity.

The plot is that you are scientist Gordon Freeman, on the run in City 17. 20 years before, scientists in the Black Mesa Research Facility accidentally released a genetically mutated alien species made up of Vortigaunts and Headcrabs. Later, their population overloaded and Black Mesa became instable, which drived to the attention of the Combine army. Soon after the alien species population was at peak, the Combines took over the city.

In the game, you first start out in the train station, where the mysterious G-Man transported you. After that, you reunite with your Lambda buddies: Barney, Alyx, Kleiner, and Eli. You try to teleport to Eli's lab, but the teleportation fails. After that, you're on your own.

The main plot is that you are trying to exterminate the vicious and abusive Combine army to bring the entire city and the world back in place. But, you must go through a series of trials to avoid any direct contact with any Combine army (like a series of Combines)

In general, this game is just downright amazing. The graphics are great for its age, it brings a realistic feel, and the AI is spectacularly done in such detail I can't even describe.

The gameplay is superior and more fluent compared to other games of that time, which makes it WAY ahead of its time. Even though there were other games released around that time like CS:S which has been critically acclaimed for its graphics, HL2's is FAR better; light years better.

The realism is just... REAL! It actually makes you feel like that you are Gordon Freeman and it brings strong visuals to your brain what it would look like if you were actually stuck in Gordon's situation.

I'm so glad I actually forked out only $10 for the best PC game of all time. Ever since I got it, I've been EXTREMELY addicted to this game. I can't even believe I just started playing it three days ago! This game is a fun one, and it runs over the word fun" and turns it into "extremely convivial." How about you guys pick this game up
date: and prepare to have the best time in your life! This game will fill a big gap in your game brain
recommended:
like 80 percent of it.

Prepare to be amazed at what Valve did here!

10.0
